{{Infobox women by region | image = Blonde girl from Poland.jpg | caption = Portrait of a young woman from Poland. | gii = 0.139 (2013) | gii_rank = 26th out of 152 | gii_ref = <ref name=gii>{{cite web|title=Table 4: Gender Inequality Index|url=http://hdr.undp.org/en/content/table-4-gender-inequality-index|publisher=United Nations Development Programme|accessdate=7 November 2014}}</ref> | matdeath = 5 (2010) | womparl = 28% (2017)<ref>https://data.worldbank.org/indicator/SG.GEN.PARL.ZS</ref> | femed = 79.4% (2012) | womlab = 59.5% ([[employment rate]] [[OECD]] definition, 2017)<ref name="stats.oecd.org">http://stats.oecd.org/Index.aspx?DatasetCode=LFS_SEXAGE_I_R#</ref> | ggg = 0.7031 (2013) | ggg_rank = 54th | ggg_ref = <ref name="ggr">{{cite web|title=The Global Gender Gap Report 2013|url=http://www3.weforum.org/docs/WEF_GenderGap_Report_2013.pdf#page=20|publisher=World Economic Forum|pages=12–13}}</ref> }} The character of '''women in Poland''' has been shaped by the [[history of Poland]], its [[culture of Poland|culture]], and [[politics of Poland|politics]].<ref>{{cite web|title=Polish women|url=http://www.polishmarriage.org/polishwomen.html|publisher=polishmarriage.org|accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref> The status of women in the country is one of contradictions. Poland has a long history of feminist activism, and was one of the first nations in Europe to enact [[women's suffrage]]. However, Poland is also strongly influenced by conservative social views shaped by the powerful presence of [[Catholic Church in Poland|Roman Catholicism in Poland]].
==History== [[File:EU 27 Gender Pay Gap 2014.png|thumb|left|Bar graph showing the gender pay gap in European countries|[[Gender pay gap]] in average gross hourly earnings in the [[European Union|EU]] member states, according to [[Eurostat]] 2014.<ref name="EC stats">[[European Commission]]. [http://ec.europa.eu/justice/gender-equality/gender-pay-gap/situation-europe/index_en.htm ''The situation in the EU''.] Retrieved on July 12, 2011.</ref> Poland has one of the lowest gender pay gaps in the EU.]] {{Women in society sidebar}} The history of women on the territory of present-day Poland has many roots, and has been strongly influenced by [[Catholic Church in Poland|Roman Catholicism in Poland]]. [[Feminism in Poland]] has a long history, and has traditionally been divided into seven periods, beginning arguably with the 18th century [[Polish Enlightenment|enlightenment]], followed by [[first-wave feminism]].<ref>Łoch, Eugenia (ed.) 2001. ''Modernizm i feminizm. Postacie kobiece w literaturze polskiej i obcej''. [[Lublin]]: Wydawnictwo Uniwersytetu M.Curie-Skłodowskiej, p.44</ref> The first four early periods coincided with the foreign [[partitions of Poland]], which resulted in the elimination of the sovereign Polish state for 123 years.<ref name="Davies">Davies, Norman. ''[[God's Playground]]: a history of Poland.'' Revised Edition. Oxford: Clarendon Press, 2005.</ref>
=== 1918-1939 === Poland was among the first nations to grant women legal rights: [[women's suffrage]] was delivered in 1918,<ref>https://www.britannica.com/topic/woman-suffrage</ref> after the country regained independence that year, following the 123-year period of partition and foreign rule. Despite the improvement of the state's policies regarding women rights, Polish women still faced discrimination on various levels. The interwar period was the time of forming of the "[[glass ceiling]]" concept in Polish society.<ref name=":4">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/830511460|title=Kobiety w (polskiej) sferze publicznej|last=Natalia.|first=Krzyżanowska,|isbn=9788377801628|location=Toruń|oclc=830511460}}</ref> Women had to compete with men mainly for the well paid, high prestige positions.<ref name=":4" /> Lower salary was primarily a result of the lower efficiency of the female employees in the physical labor but was later implemented in the other sectors where women were equally productive.<ref name=":4" />
=== Communism === During the [[Polish communism|communist era]], women were ostensibly granted equal legal rights, and the official government rhetoric was one of supporting [[gender equality]], but as in other communist states, the civil rights of both men and women were merely symbolic, as the system was an authoritarian one. Despite remaining ''[[de facto]]'' subordinated to male authority, women did see some gains under the communist régime, such as better access to education and to a more equal involvement in the workforce. Women's better situation during the communist era was significantly influenced by the socialist pro-birth position, seeking the increase in the population.<ref name=":0">{{Cite journal|last=Fodor|first=Eva|last2=Glass|first2=Christy|last3=Kawachi|first3=Janette|last4=Popescu|first4=Livia|date=2002-2012|title=Family policies and gender in Hungary, Poland, and Romania|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0967-067X(02)00030-2|journal=Communist and Post-Communist Studies|volume=35|issue=4|pages=475–490|doi=10.1016/s0967-067x(02)00030-2|issn=0967-067X|via=}}</ref> Pro-natalist policies were implemented by "generous maternity leave beneﬁts and state contributions to child rearing".<ref name=":0" /> After the [[martial law in Poland]] first publications discussing feminist ideas appeared in the public sphere, sometimes considered as the cover for the actual social situation.<ref name=":42">{{Cite book|url=https://www.worldcat.org/oclc/830511460|title=Kobiety w (polskiej) sferze publicznej|last=Natalia.|first=Krzyżanowska,|isbn=9788377801628|location=Toruń|oclc=830511460}}</ref> Society mainly perceived feminism as the ideology alien to the Polish culture and mentality.<ref name=":42" /> Communist leaders claimed that women in Poland obtained equal rights as the result of the socialistic social processes, and used that statement as the explanation for the lack and no need of feminism in Poland.<ref name=":42" /> One of the Polish communists described a typical feminist as an "eccentric and aggressive witch, being anyway a lesbian, that would like to see a man go on all fours by her leg."<ref name=":42" />
=== Post-communism === The [[fall of communism in Poland]] meant the shaking up of the politics and economy of the country, and initial economic and social destabilization. In the post-socialist workforce, women occupied mainly sectors of lower economic priority and light industries, due to factors such as selecting types of education and training more compatible with family life (usually paid less), discrimination and gender stereotypes. <ref name=":22">{{Cite journal|last=Łobodzińska|first=Barbara|date=2000-2001|title=Polish women's gender-segregated education and employment|url=https://doi.org/10.1016/S0277-5395(99)00090-4|journal=Women's Studies International Forum|volume=23|issue=1|pages=49–71|doi=10.1016/s0277-5395(99)00090-4|issn=0277-5395|access-date=17 July 2018|via=}}</ref> This pattern of the gender employment inequality was viewed by majority as the result of the female's primary role in the family, as well as deeply rooted Polish culture and tradition of the [[Patriarchy|patriarchal system]].<ref name=":22"/> The transition period was especially difficult for women, although men were also negatively affected. As of 2017, the employment rate for women aged 20–64 was 63.6%, compared to the men's rate of 78.2%.<ref>https://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/refreshTableAction.do?tab=table&plugin=1&pcode=t2020_10&language=en</ref> Although Poland has an image of a conservative country, being often depicted as such in the Western media, Poland actually has high numbers of professional women, and women in business,<ref>http://www.grantthornton.global/en/press/press-releases-2015/women-in-business-2015/</ref> and it also has one of the lowest [[gender pay gap]]s in the European Union.<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/justice/gender-equality/gender-pay-gap/situation-europe/index_en.htm</ref> One of the obstacles faced by contemporary women in Poland is the [[Abortion in Poland|anti-abortion law]]. Together with the "Polish Mother" myth perspective, banning of abortion is used to encourage women to have many children.<ref name=":22"/><ref name=":1">{{Cite journal|last=Imbierowicz|first=Agnieszka|date=1 June 2012|title=The Polish Mother on the Defensive? The Transformation of the Myth and Its Impact on the Motherhood of Polish Women.|url=https://doaj.org/article/3bb9a441a11040118007f2453a9ba3a9|journal=Journal of Education Culture and Society|volume=2012 (1)|pages=140–153|access-date=17 July 2018|via=}}</ref> This ideology reinforces the view that women's place is in the home.<ref name=":22" /> The Polish Mother symbol is a stereotype strongly stuck in the Polish consciousness and was shaped by the turbulent history of the nation.<ref name=":1" /> During the long occupation time the responsibility for maintaining the national identity fell on the mothers, whose main task was the "upbringing of children".<ref name=":1" /> Despite the strict legislation and the [[conservative]] political discourse, Poland has one of the lowest fertility rate in Europe.<ref>http://ec.europa.eu/eurostat/tgm/table.do?tab=table&init=1&language=en&pcode=tps00199&plugin=1</ref>
The status of women in contemporary Poland must be understood in the context of its political scene and of the role that the church plays in society. This is especially true withy regard to [[reproductive rights]]. Poland is a country strongly influenced by [[Roman Catholicism]], and religion often shapes politics and social views. [[Law and Justice]], abbreviated to '''PiS''', is a [[national conservatism|national-conservative]],<ref name="Ashgate">{{Citation |first1= Vít |last1=Hloušek |first2=Lubomír |last2=Kopeček |title= Origin, Ideology and Transformation of Political Parties: East-Central and Western Europe Compared |publisher=Ashgate |year= 2010 |page= 196}}</ref><ref name="Nordsieck">{{Citation |first=Wolfram |last= Nodsieck |title=Poland |work=Parties and Elections in Europe |url= http://parties-and-elections.eu/poland.html |accessdate=28 March 2012}}</ref> and [[Christian democracy|Christian democratic]]<ref name="Hierlemann">{{cite book|editor1=Dominik Hierlemann |title=Lobbying der katholischen Kirche: Das Einflussnetz des Klerus in Polen|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=83aABwAAQBAJ&dq=pis+christdemokratisch&hl=de&source=gbs_navlinks_s|year=2005|publisher=Springer-Verlag|isbn=978-3531146607|page=131}}</ref><ref name="orf">{{cite web|title=Unentschlossene als Zünglein an der Waage|url=http://orf.at/stories/2279771/2279772/|website=News ORF|accessdate=24 May 2015}}</ref> [[List of political parties in Poland|political party in Poland]]. With 237 seats in the [[Sejm]] and 66 in the [[Senate of Poland|Senate]], it is currently the largest party in the [[National Assembly of the Republic of Poland|Polish parliament]].
Poland is part of the [[European Union]] (EU) [[2004 enlargement of the European Union|since 2004]]. As such, it is subject to the EU [[Directive (European Union)|directives]]. As part of the EU, Poland is socially influenced by 'Western' views, but there are regional differences between the western and the eastern parts of the country - "[[Poland A and B]]". Poland also has a significant [[rural]] population: about 40%,<ref>https://www.cia.gov/library/publications/the-world-factbook/fields/2212.html</ref> which is deeply conservative.<ref>https://www.theguardian.com/world/2015/oct/25/law-and-justice-poland-drift-to-right</ref>
== Old Polish customs == In old-time Poland customs of the people differed based on the social status. Polish customs derived from the other European traditions, however, they usually came to Poland later than in other countries.<ref name=":3">{{Cite book|url=http://hdl.handle.net/2027/uc1.b5106109|title=Zwyczaje towarzyskie w dawnej Polsce.|last=Kosinski|first=Waclaw|date=1921|publisher=Sandomierz,|year=|isbn=|location=|pages=}}</ref> The example of the [[chivalry]] illustrates the approach of the medieval class towards women. The entire idea of the chivalry was based on the almost divine worship of the female, and every knight had to have his "[[Lady|lady"]] ("dama") as the object of (very often platonic) love.<ref name=":3" /> Knights felt obligated to take a patronage over their ladies.<ref name=":3" /> Women in the old Poland were perceived as the soul of the company during the social gatherings.<ref name=":3" /> In old Poland woman had a preeminent social position. Referring to girls as ''panny'' (''ladies'') which derives from the Polish word ''pan'' (''sir'') unlike ''chłopcy'' (''boys'') which comes from the word ''chłop'' (''peasant'') is the sign of respect shown towards women.<ref name=":3" /> Long time before emancipation movements women in Poland made their social role very important, mainly due to th numerous conflicts and threats that kept man out of homes.<ref name=":3" /> Political and economic situation required women to become self-sufficient and valiant.<ref name=":3" /> Different from the modern times were also outfits of the Polish women. The mid-XVI century' apparels contained diverse types of decorations and accessories.<ref name=":3" /> Women's headwear included decorative wreaths, veils, and various hatbands. Among the notable elements of the old-time outfit were "long, satin dresses" decorated with the gold and pearls, as well as the "aureate slippers".<ref name=":3" />
== Women in sports == Polish women have earned a special place in the country's sports. The top 3 place for the most wins in the annual most popular sportsperson contest, the [[Plebiscite of Przegląd Sportowy]], are occupied by women.<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://pl.wikipedia.org/wiki/Plebiscyt_„Przeglądu_Sportowego”#Statystyki|title=Plebiscyt Przeglądu Sportowego- Statystyki|last=|first=|date=|website=|archive-url=|archive-date=|dead-url=|access-date=}}</ref> Among the most prominent Polish women athletes are [[Justyna Kowalczyk]], [[Irena Szewińska]] and [[Stanisława Walasiewicz]]. In the [[2016 Summer Olympics|2016 Rio Summer Olympic Games]] Poland was represented by 101 women athletes. They won 8 out of 11 medals for Poland, including two gold medals. <ref>{{Citation|title=Polska na Letnich Igrzyskach Olimpijskich 2016|date=2018-05-03|url=https://pl.wikipedia.org/w/index.php?title=Polska_na_Letnich_Igrzyskach_Olimpijskich_2016&oldid=53366756|work=Wikipedia, wolna encyklopedia|language=pl|access-date=2018-07-31}}</ref>
==Notable women in Polish history== The important women in Poland's early history include: [[Swietoslava]] (sometimes confused as being [[Sigrid the Haughty]] or [[Gunnhild, Mother of Kings|Gunhilda]]; also known as [[Storrada]]), the daughter of [[Mieszko the First]] and [[Dobrawa of Bohemia]]; [[Katarzyna Jagiellonka]] (also known as Catherine Jagiello or Katarrina Jegellonica); [[Dobrawa of Bohemia|Dobrawa]] herself (wife of Mieszko the First), the daughter of the Duke of Bohemia; Jadwiga (Hedwig), the daughter of a Hungarian king.<ref>{{cite web|title=Women in Poland's Early History|url=http://culture.polishsite.us/articles/art390fr.htm|accessdate=2 November 2013}}</ref> During the Enlightenment, two women stand out: [[Barbara Sanguszko]], hostess, writer and philanthropist and her granddaughter, [[Tekla Teresa Lubienska]], writer and mother of a [[Magnates of Poland and Lithuania|magnate dynasty]]. [[Emilia Plater]] was an early revolutionary associated with the [[November Uprising]]. In music, the composer and pianist, [[Maria Szymanowska]] won acclaim from [[St-Petersburg]] to [[London, England|London]]. [[Marie Sklodowska]] was a [[Nobel Prize]] winning scientist who moved to France in the late 19th-c. Many notable women contributed to Poland's independence movement at the dawn of the 20th-c. These included, the activist and military officers, [[Aleksandra Zagórska]] and the mostly forgotten, [[Wanda Gertz]] as well as [[Anna Walentynowicz]], co-founder of the anti-communistic "Solidarity" ("Solidarność"). [[Wisława Szymborska]] was a Polish poet, recipient of the Nobel Prize in 1996.

'''Gjergj Elez Alia''' or '''Đerzelez Alija''' is a popular legendary hero in epic poetry and literature in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]], [[Gora (region)|Gora]] and in northern [[Albania]]. Muslims from [[Bosnian Krajina]] modeled the poetic image of Alija Đerzelez after the image of Serbian (Christian) [[Prince Marko]], based on the historic person [[Ali Bey Mihaloğlu]]. Songs about Đerzelez Alija were transmitted by bilingual singers from [[South Slavs|South Slavic]] milieu (some would say back) to northern [[Albanians|Albanian]] milieu, where he is known as ''Gjergj Elez Alia''. ==Name== The most popular spelling of the name is ''Đerzelez Alija'', while there are many variants, such as {{lang-bs|Đerđelez Alija}} (Djerdjelez Alija), {{lang-sq|Gjergj Elez Alia}},{{cite book|last=Fishta|first=Gjergj|title=The highland lute: (Lahuta e Malcís) : the Albanian national epic|year=2005|publisher=I.B. Tauris|location=London|isbn=978-1-84511-118-2|url=https://books.google.rs/books?id=j7tLgANw8hAC&pg=PA402|author2=Robert Elsie|accessdate=11 November 2011|page=402}} {{lang-tr|Gürz Ilyas}}, and {{lang-hu|Gerz Ilyas}}. His name is derived from the [[Turkish language|Turkish]] word ''gürzi'' ([[mace (bludgeon)|mace]]) and means warrior with the mace.{{Citation |last= Norris |first= H. T. |title= Islam in the Balkans : religion and society between Europe and the Arab world |url= https://books.google.rs/books?id=kTcRDKnYf2cC&pg=PA159 |accessdate= 25 November 2011 |year= 1993 |publisher=University of South Carolina Press |location= Columbia, S.C. |isbn= 978-0-87249-977-5 |oclc= 28067651 |page= 159 |quote= ... They say that this is where his name originated, for Djurzelez means the warior with the mace ... with the epic Djerzelez. In a Turkish census defter [administrative register] of 1485 a timar [feudal property] of Gjerz-Eljaz is recorded for nahija [small administrative area] of Dobrun, near town of Višegrad}}{{Citation |last= Velikonja |first= Mitja |title= Religious separation and political intolerance in Bosnia-Herzegovina |url= https://books.google.rs/books?id=Rf8P-7ExoKYC&pg=PA86 |accessdate= 25 November 2011 |year= 2003 |publisher=Texas A & M University Press |location= College Station |isbn= 978-1-58544-989-7 |oclc= 53971200 |page= 86 |quote= ... his name means "the warrior with mace" }} ==Historical background== Some historians believed that epic figure of Đerzelez was inspired by [[Ali Bey Mihaloglu]]{{cite book|last=Škrijelj|first=Redžep|title=Alamanah 31-32|year=2005|location=Podgorica|url=http://www.almanah.co.me/Ostale/PDF/casopis/Almanah%2031-32.pdf|accessdate=22 June 2011|page=156|language=Serbian|quote=Istoričari Stojan Novaković i Milenko Vukićević su postavili hipotezu da je Đerzelez Alija u stvari Ali-beg, prvi sandžak-beg Smedereva (Semendere) i Srbije po padu Despotovine (1459).}}{{harvnb|Hadžijahić|1934|p=8}}{{quote| Aleksej Olesnički tvrdi...da je Đerzelez Alija identičan sa Mihal-oglu Ali begom...[Aleksej Olesnički claims ... that Djerzelez Alija can be identified as Mihal-oglu Ali beg]}} an [[Ottoman Empire|Ottoman]] military commander in 15th century and the first [[sanjakbey]] of the [[Sanjak of Smederevo]]. According to Ottoman census of 1485 he was in charge for [[nahiya]] of Dobrun near [[Višegrad]] as his ''[[timar]]'' (land grant). There is a ''turbe'' (mausoleum) in the village of Gerzovo (near [[Mrkonjić Grad]], [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]]) which according to legend is his burial place.{{cite book|last=Mujezinović|first=Mehmed|title=Islamska epigrafika u Bosni i Hercegovini: Bosanska krajina, zapadna Bosna i Hercegovina [Islamic inscriptions -- Bosnia and Hercegovina]|year=1974|publisher=Veselin Masleša|location=Sarajevo |page=12|quote=ĐERZELEZOVO TURBE NA GERZOVU Na Gerzovu Polju, kojih tridesetak kilometara od Mrkonjić-Grada idući prema Šipovu, nalazi se turbe koje narodna predanja pripisuje legendarnom junaku Aliji Đerzelezu. [Djerdjelez's turbe on Gerzovo. On Gerzovo Polje, some thirty kilometers from Mrkonjic Grad to Sipovo there is a turbe which peoples legend attribute to legendary hero Djerdjelez Alia. ]}}{{cite book|last=Tomašević|first=Nebojša|title=Treasures of Yugoslavia: an encyclopedic touring guide|year=1982|publisher=Yugoslavia public| page=305|quote=The mausoleum (turbeh) at Gerzovo is traditionally attributed to epic ballad hero, Alija Djerzelez.}} The first written record of the epic figure of Đerzelez (in the form of "Ali-beg") was a form of South Slavic ''[[bugarštica]]'' (long form epic and ballad poem), ''The Marriage of [[Vuk the Dragon-Despot]]'', recorded by Đuro Matei at the end of 17th or beginning of 18th century.{{harvnb|Hadžijahić|1934|p=10}}{{quote|Prvi spomen Djerzelez Alije u narodnoj pjesmi sačuvao se je kod Bogišića, u bugarštici br. 13, koja nosi naslov "Kad se Vuk Ognjeni oženio". He chose not to interrupt his prayers even though he was aware of his imminent death }} [[Ivo Andrić]], the 1961 winner of the [[Nobel Prize in literature]], wrote ''Put Alije Đerzeleza'' [The Journey of Alija Đerzelez], published in 1920, after two fragments (''Djerzelez at the Inn'' and ''Djerzelez on the Road'') were published in 1918 and 1919.{{cite book|last=Hobdell Jackson|first=William Thomas|title=European Writers|year=1990|publisher=Scribner|location=New York|isbn=978-0-684-16594-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=SLhZAAAAYAAJ&q=djerzelez&dq=djerzelez&hl=en&ei=mKrOTr_YNqHE4gT1keVC&sa=X&oi=book_result&ct=result&resnum=1&ved=0CDMQ6AEwADgK|author2=George Stade|accessdate=24 November 2011|page=1753|quote=The first complete short story, "Put Alije Djerzeleza," was published in 1920, although two fragments, "Djerzelez u hanu" (Djerzelez at the Inn) and "Djerzelez na putu" (Djerzelez on the Road) had appeared, in issues of Knizevni jug in 1918 and 1919.}} One of the oldest houses in [[Sarajevo]], "The House of Alija Đerzelez", is named after him.{{cite web|url=http://www.sarajevo-tourism.com/eng/sarajevothroughhistory.htm|title=sarajevothroughhistory| publisher=Sarajevo-tourism web site|accessdate=24 November 2011|archiveurl=https://www.webcitation.org/query?url=http%3A%2F%2Fwww.sarajevo-tourism.com%2Feng%2Fsarajevothroughhistory.htm&date=2011-11-24|archivedate=24 November 2011|quote=THE HOUSE OF ALIJA DJERZELEZ One of the oldest preserved authentic Bosnian houses. It is located on Sagrdzija Street in the old part of town. The house was named after an epic character – Alija Djerzelez.}} There are streets in several towns in [[Bosnia and Herzegovina]] ([[Bihać]], [[Gračanica, Bosnia and Herzegovina|Gračanica]], [[Zenica]], etc.) named after him. ==Albanian folklore== {{Wikisource|The Song of Gjergj Elez Alia|The Song of Gjergj Elez Alia}} In [[Albanian folklore]], Gjergj Elez Alia was a great warrior. The song ''Gjergj Elez Alia'' was recorded by [[Bernardin Palaj]] and [[Donat Kurti]] in [[Nikaj-Mërtur|Nikaj]] ([[Tropojë District]]) and published in Tirana in 1937.{{harvnb|Elsie|2004|p=xi}}{{quote| Gjergj Elez Alia, recorded in Nikaj (District of Tropoja). Published in Visaret e Kombit, Vol II, ed. Bernandin Palay and Donat Kurti (Tirana 1937)}} The song is usually sung accompanied by the ''lahuta'' ([[gusle]]), or occasionally with ''[[çifteli]]'', by the ''rapsodi'' (performer).{{cite book|title= A Dictionary of Albanian Religion, Mythology, and Folk Culture|last= Elsie|first= Robert |authorlink= Robert Elsie|year= 2001|publisher= NYU Press|location= |isbn= 0-8147-2214-8|page= 101|url= https://books.google.com/books?id=aAtQZ0vjf5gC&pg=PA101}} The song is part of the larger cycle of the ''[[Albanian Songs of the Frontier Warriors]]'' ({{lang-sq|Këngë Kreshnikësh or Cikli i Kreshnikëve}}) that crystallized in the 17th and 18th centuries and recorded in written form in the first decades of 20th century by the [[Franciscan]] priests [[Shtjefën Gjeçovi]] and Bernardin Palaj.{{harvnb|Elsie|2004|p=xi}}{{quote|There is general consensus nowadays that The Songs of the Frontier Warriors crystallized in the 17th and 18th centuries. The Songs of the Frontier Warriors were first recorded in the early decades of 20th century by Franciscan priests...}} Although they were transmitted from South Slavic milieu of Bosnia they are not simply translated from Serbo-Croatian, but have independently evolved in the northern Albanian highlands.{{harvnb|Elsie|2004|p=xi}}{{quote|Despite transmission from a Bosnian Slav milieu, the Songs of Frontier Warriors are by no means simply translations of Serbo Croatian epic verse. They have undergone continuous and independent evolution...and are...a product of the creative genius of the northern Albanian highlands}} {{cquote|Gjergj Elez Alia had nine wounds on his body and lay suffering for nine years in his house and everybody had forgotten him. Only his sister took care of him night and day for nine years. Then news came that another enemy, [[Balozi i Zi]] (black knight) had come from the sea and was killing people and destroying villages every day.
One day Gjergj felt some drops of water on his face and thought that his house had become so old that the rain was coming in. His sister told him that it was not the rain, but her tears on his face. She told him that Balozi had requested her and sooner or later would come to get her. Gjergj then told her to take his horse and make it ready for war, as he was going to fight against the horrible Baloz. He met Baloz the next day and had the fight; Gjergj was victorious. He returned home to his sister and as they hugged with joy, both their hearts stopped beating and they died instantly together. They were then buried in the same grave and the place was never forgotten. Everyone that passed by stopped to remember his great actions.}} ==References== {{reflist|2}} ==Sources== *{{cite book|last=Elsie|first=Robert|title=Songs of the frontier warriors|year=2004|publisher=Bolchazy-Carducci Publishers|isbn=978-0-86516-412-3|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=5xgxBY81S7IC&pg=PR11|ref=harv}} *{{cite book|last=Popović|first=Tanya|title=Prince Marko: the hero of South Slavic epics|year=1988|publisher=Syracuse University Press|location=Syracuse, N.Y.|isbn=978-0-8156-2444-8|url=https://books.google.com/books?id=ok93aZ27r-oC&pg=PA164|accessdate=24 November 2011|ref=harv}} *{{Citation |last= Hadžijahić |first= Muhamed |title= Narodne pjesme o Djerzelez Aliji [Folk songs about Djerzelez Alija] |year= 1934 |publisher= Št.
